elements.content: Three water-stable luminescent MOFs [Zn4(bptc)2(NMP)3(DMF)­(H2O)2] n (1-a), [Cd4­(bptc)2­(NMP)3­(DMF)2­(H2O)1] n (1-b), and {[Zn2­(bptc)­(DMA)­(H2O)2]·​(DMA)2·​H2O} n (2), possessing similar chemical components (M2:L1:Sol3) and topology structures, were synthesized by solvents control. Their excellent sensing on iron­(III) cation and nitroaromatic explosives (NACs) with great selectivity, sensitivity and a high K sv (4.54 × 104 for 1-b on PNP) were observed by quenching effects. Furthermore, Zn-MOFs exhibit interesting stimuli-responsive luminescence enhancement after the encapsulation of a series of IIIB cations stimulated different luminescent emitting and intensity enhancement through host–guest processes of the pores in MOFs, especially for two distinct responses of Zn-MOF on a Tb3+ cation.

elements.content: Incorporation of inorganic and organic luminescence components into the host–guest materials has attracted great attention for their excellent applications in polarized emission, light-emitting diodes (LED), environmental monitoring, and biotechnology. The metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) which are also called porous coordination polymers (PCPs) represent a relatively novel class of hybrid inorganic–organic porous crystalline materials, which have been widely studied in the fields including catalysis, gas storage, separation, sensing, bioimaging, drug delivery, magnetism, electrochemical energy storage, and conversion. Recently, MOFs are widely researched for their fascinating coordination structures and unusual properties, such as uniform structured nanoscale cavities, high surface area, chemical tunability, as well as excellent chemical and thermal stability. The usage of MOFs as functional luminescence host–guest materials has made great progress, however, which is still at the early stage. To date, some Zn- or Cd-based rigid porous MOFs are promising candidates as (1) the sensors on metal cations, anions, small organic molecules, and (2) the capsules for ions, drugs, medicines, due to their unique porous structures and host–guest luminescent emissions. Exploration of suitable MOFs with stimuli-responsive specific luminescence quenching or enhancement on target ions or molecules through a host–gust process is a significant, but challenging, task.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Incorporation of inorganic and organic luminescence components into the host-guest materials has attracted great attention for their excellent applications in polarized emission, light-emitting diodes (LED), environmental monitoring, and biotechnology. The metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) which are also called porous coordination polymers (PCPs) represent a relatively novel class of hybrid inorganic-organic porous crystalline materials, which have been widely studied in the fields including catalysis, gas storage, separation, sensing, bioimaging, drug delivery, magnetism, electrochemical energy storage, and conversion. Recently, MOFs are widely researched for their fascinating coordination structures and unusual properties, such as uniform structured nanoscale cavities, high surface area, chemical tunability, as well as excellent chemical and thermal stability. The usage of MOFs as functional luminescence host-guest materials has made great progress, however, which is still at the early stage. To date, some Zn- or Cd-based rigid porous MOFs are promising candidates as (1) the sensors on metal cations, anions, small organic molecules, and (2) the capsules for ions, drugs, medicines, due to their unique porous structures and host-guest luminescent emissions. Exploration of suitable MOFs with stimuli-responsive specific luminescence quenching or enhancement on target ions or molecules through a host-gust process is a significant, but challenging, task.

elements.content: Numerous transition metal ions play crucial roles in various metabolic processes and industrial application, which are widely distributed in the environment and biosystem. Especially, Fe3+ ion is vital for oxygen storage and transport, and electron transfer in DNA/RNA synthesis on the cellular level. Both the iron shortage and the surplus may result in the skin diseases, agrypnia, iron deficiency anemia (IDA), and decreased immunity in the human body. Compared with other solid-state inorganic–organic compounds, the detection and absorption of some porous MOFs on Fe3+ ion show superior sensitivity, efficiency and capacity, which have been made great efforts. Besides, nitroaromatic explosives (NACs), such as nitrobenzene (NB), m-nitrotoluene (MNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), p-nitrophenol (PNP), etc., have increased the concerns for environmental pollution due to their highly explosive nature and being very difficult to be detected. Since the first microporous crystalline metal–organic material for detection of trace explosives in the vapor phase was reported by Li et al. in 2009, a lot of fluorescent MOFs were synthesized and researched for sensing and detection of NACs with a fast and highly sensitive response via partial fluorescence quenching. Furthermore, owing to the unique spectroscopic properties (narrow band, larger Stokes shift, long lifetime, and so on) of lanthanide­(III) ions, Ln-loaded MOFs (encapsulating lanthanide­(III) ions in pores) provide a promising platform to optimize and transfer the luminescent emissions and have great applications for white-light-emitting (WLE) materials, fluorescence probes, and photocatalysts.·
elements.clean_text: Numerous transition metal ions play crucial roles in various metabolic processes and industrial application, which are widely distributed in the environment and biosystem. Especially, Fe3+ ion is vital for oxygen storage and transport, and electron transfer in DNA/RNA synthesis on the cellular level. Both the iron shortage and the surplus may result in the skin diseases, agrypnia, iron deficiency anemia (IDA), and decreased immunity in the human body. Compared with other solid-state inorganic-organic compounds, the detection and absorption of some porous MOFs on Fe3+ ion show superior sensitivity, efficiency and capacity, which have been made great efforts. Besides, nitroaromatic explosives (NACs), such as nitrobenzene (NB), m-nitrotoluene (MNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), p-nitrophenol (PNP), etc., have increased the concerns for environmental pollution due to their highly explosive nature and being very difficult to be detected. Since the first microporous crystalline metal-organic material for detection of trace explosives in the vapor phase was reported by Li et al. in 2009, a lot of fluorescent MOFs were synthesized and researched for sensing and detection of NACs with a fast and highly sensitive response via partial fluorescence quenching. Furthermore, owing to the unique spectroscopic properties (narrow band, larger Stokes shift, long lifetime, and so on) of lanthanide(III) ions, Ln-loaded MOFs (encapsulating lanthanide(III) ions in pores) provide a promising platform to optimize and transfer the luminescent emissions and have great applications for white-light-emitting (WLE) materials, fluorescence probes, and photocatalysts.⋅

elements.content: On the basis of the above consideration, we have synthesized three water-stable MOFs [Zn4­(bptc)2­(NMP)3­(DMF)­(H2O)2] n (1-a), [Cd4­(bptc)2­(NMP)3­(DMF)2­(H2O)1] n (1-b), and {[Zn2­(bptc)­(DMA)­(H2O)2]·​(DMA)2·​H2O} n (2), based on a tetra­carboxylic acid biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetra­car­boxylic acid (H4bptc), which possess similar chemical components and topology structures by solvents control. The three MOFs show excellent detection abilities on iron­(III) cation and NACs. In addition, the encapsulation of a series of Ln3+ cations could generate different luminescent emitting Ln-loaded materials and the luminescent intensity is greatly enhanced.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above consideration, we have synthesized three water-stable MOFs [Zn4(bptc)2(NMP)3(DMF)(H2O)2] n  (1-a), [Cd4(bptc)2(NMP)3(DMF)2(H2O)1] n  (1-b), and {[Zn2(bptc)(DMA)(H2O)2]⋅(DMA)2⋅H2O} n  (2), based on a tetracarboxylic acid biphenyl-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptc), which possess similar chemical components and topology structures by solvents control. The three MOFs show excellent detection abilities on iron(III) cation and NACs. In addition, the encapsulation of a series of Ln3+ cations could generate different luminescent emitting Ln-loaded materials and the luminescent intensity is greatly enhanced.

elements.content: All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptc) was obtained from Chemsoon Chemical Co. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a vario MICRO cube elemental analyzer. Photoluminescence spectra were measured on a JASCO FP-6500 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. Thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449F5 thermal analyzer in a dynamic atmosphere of dinitrogen (flow rate = 30 cm3 min–1). The sample was heated in an alumina crucible at a rate of 10 °C min–1. The powders’ X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded with PANalytical Empyrean by using Cu Ka radiation (k = 1.5418 Å) from 5° < 2θ < 50° in 2° steps at 1 min per step.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Biphenyl-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptc) was obtained from Chemsoon Chemical Co. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a vario MICRO cube elemental analyzer. Photoluminescence spectra were measured on a JASCO FP-6500 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. Thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449F5 thermal analyzer in a dynamic atmosphere of dinitrogen (flow rate = 30 cm3 min-1). The sample was heated in an alumina crucible at a rate of 10 °C min-1. The powders' X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded with PANalytical Empyrean by using Cu Ka radiation (k = 1.5418 Å) from 5° < 2θ < 50° in 2° steps at 1 min per step.

elements.content: A solid mixture of biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetra­carboxylic acid (H4bptc, 25.08 mg, 0.076 mmol), and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (101.74 mg, 0.342 mmol), dissolved in a mixture of 4.0 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) and 4.0 mL of N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) in a sealed 20 mL screw-top glass bottle, was heated at 85 °C for 24 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature for 10 h, and the resulting crystals were filtered from the reaction mixture and washed with DMF.

A solid mixture of biphenyl-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptc, 25.08 mg, 0.076 mmol), and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (50.87 mg, 0.171 mmol), dissolved in a mixture of dimethylacetamide (DMA)/H2O (4.0/0.8 mL) and HBF4 (2 drops) in a sealed 20 mL screw-top glass bottle, was heated at 85 °C for 24 h. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K using a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer. The radiation used was graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection and structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data for the complex are given in . The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS 97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL 97. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. In the case of disorder, all atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. One of the DMF molecules was modeled for disorder over two positions, with occupancy 50%:50%. The hydrogen atoms on the solvent molecules were omitted from the model. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON v1.15, ORTEP-3v2, and WinGX system Ver-1.64. The selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1–2 are summarized in Tables S8–S10. CCDC numbers: 1869158–1869160 for 1-a, 1-b, 2.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K using a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer. The radiation used was graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection and structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data for the complex are given in . The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS 97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL 97. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. In the case of disorder, all atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. One of the DMF molecules was modeled for disorder over two positions, with occupancy 50%:50%. The hydrogen atoms on the solvent molecules were omitted from the model. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON v1.15, ORTEP-3v2, and WinGX system Ver-1.64. The selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1-2 are summarized in Tables S8-S10. CCDC numbers: 1869158-1869160 for 1-a, 1-b, 2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that the compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with Pbcn space group. As shown in a, the crystal asymmetric unit of 1-a contains four Zn­(II) ions, two bptc anions, three coordinated NMP solvent molecules, one DMF solvent molecule, and two water molecules. elements.content: The 3D structure of 1-a is shown in c, which gives approximately 1.30 × 1.39 nm parallel one-dimensional channels along the b axis. The NMP and DMF solvents molecules bond with metal ions and fill into the pores to support the 3D framework. As the d shows, the binuclear Zn­(II) atoms bond with four bptc ligands, owing to the steric hindrance between four ligands, which is simplified as a distorted tetrahedron connected node. The six inclined angles of the Zn1–Zn2 tetrahedron are 86.556(4)°, 93.737(4)°, 111.409(5)°, 116.755(5)°, 118.497(5)°, 132.118(6)°. The inclined angles for the Zn3–Zn4 tetrahedron are 83.760(3)°, 97.912(3)°, 107.847(4)°, 112.520(4)°, 125.253(5)°, and 127.422(4)°. The bptc ligand connects with four zinc binuclear cluster, showing a distorted quadrilateral connected node. The four inclined angles of the two bptc ligands quadrilateral are 92.822(4)°, 96.240(5)°, 81.061(4)°, and 88.901(5)° for one, and 82.088(4)°, 88.601(3)°, 90.615(5)°, and 100.335(3)° for another. The 3D topology of 1-a gives two different helical chains with the pitch of 1.31 nm along the c axis (e). The extended length of the 1D channel is 1.89 nm which contains two parallel arranged helical layers.

elements.content: Interestingly, we figure out that the crystallographic unit of three MOFs is [M2:L1:Sol3] with the metal:​ligand:​solvent ratio of 2:1:3. The solvents in three frameworks are 1.5­(NMP)­0.5­(DMF)­1­(H2O), 1.5­(NMP)­1­(DMF)­0.5­(H2O), and [Zn2(L)­(DMA)­(H2O)2] (2), which indicates the final structure difference of 1–2 was originated from the diverse solvent type and constitute. 1-a and 1-b possess the same space group Pbcn; however, 1-b has a larger pore size and the channel depth which should be attributed to the larger radius of the Cd atom and the more DMF solvent in 1-b. The coordinated solvent in 2 is only one DMA and two water, which possess small steric hindrance and induces the formation of a different space group P21/n and the pore structure.
elements.clean_text:
The Structure Analysis of 1-2 

Interestingly, we figure out that the crystallographic unit of three MOFs is [M2:L1:Sol3] with the metal:ligand:solvent ratio of 2:1:3. The solvents in three frameworks are 1.5(NMP)0.5(DMF)1(H2O), 1.5(NMP)1(DMF)0.5(H2O), and [Zn2(L)(DMA)(H2O)2] (2), which indicates the final structure difference of 1-2 was originated from the diverse solvent type and constitute. 1-a and 1-b possess the same space group Pbcn; however, 1-b has a larger pore size and the channel depth which should be attributed to the larger radius of the Cd atom and the more DMF solvent in 1-b. The coordinated solvent in 2 is only one DMA and two water, which possess small steric hindrance and induces the formation of a different space group P21/n and the pore structure.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out to confirm the phase purity of complexes 1–2. The diffraction peaks of the simulated and experimental patterns correspond well, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples of compounds 1–2 as shown in a–c. Indeed, solvent loss does not significantly affect the crystal structures, with the powder diffraction patterns remaining largely unchanged after being heated at 85 °C for 8 h. The compounds are also very stable in water. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to examine the thermal stability of the porous framework of compounds 1–2. As shown in d, an initial weight loss due to the loss of uncoordinated solvent molecules is observed in the thermogravimetric curve. A second weight loss (33.14%) occurs in the temperature range of 130–293 °C and is attributed to the loss of the four coordinated molecules. The frameworks of Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 show better thermal stability (decompose at about 400 °C) compared with Cd-MOF 1-b (decomposes at about 350 °C).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Analysis

Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out to confirm the phase purity of complexes 1-2. The diffraction peaks of the simulated and experimental patterns correspond well, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples of compounds 1-2 as shown in a-c. Indeed, solvent loss does not significantly affect the crystal structures, with the powder diffraction patterns remaining largely unchanged after being heated at 85 °C for 8 h. The compounds are also very stable in water. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to examine the thermal stability of the porous framework of compounds 1-2. As shown in d, an initial weight loss due to the loss of uncoordinated solvent molecules is observed in the thermogravimetric curve. A second weight loss (33.14%) occurs in the temperature range of 130-293 °C and is attributed to the loss of the four coordinated molecules. The frameworks of Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 show better thermal stability (decompose at about 400 °C) compared with Cd-MOF 1-b (decomposes at about 350 °C).

elements.content: The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1–2 were measured at room temperature. The free ligand H4bptc displays photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 405 nm (λex = 350 nm), which was assigned to intraligand π–π* transition. As shown in , compounds 1–2 show photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 350 nm, respectively (λex = 300 nm), which have the blue shift of 55 nm, compared with free ligand H4bptc. With Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) as a typical d10 configuration, the observed photoluminescence emissions should be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), or intraligand (π* → n/π* or π* → π) emission. The luminescent emission of MOFs is influenced by both central metal coordination and the property of coordinated ligands, which need to be considered when attempting to assemble new functional luminescent MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-2 were measured at room temperature. The free ligand H4bptc displays photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 405 nm (λex = 350 nm), which was assigned to intraligand π-π* transition. As shown in , compounds 1-2 show photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 350 nm, respectively (λex = 300 nm), which have the blue shift of 55 nm, compared with free ligand H4bptc. With Zn(II) and Cd(II) as a typical d10 configuration, the observed photoluminescence emissions should be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), or intraligand (π* → n/π* or π* → π) emission. The luminescent emission of MOFs is influenced by both central metal coordination and the property of coordinated ligands, which need to be considered when attempting to assemble new functional luminescent MOFs.

elements.content: The strong luminescence of all three MOFs encouraged us to examine their potentials for sensing common organic solvent molecules. The fluorescence properties of 1–2 in different solvent emulsions were investigated. The solvents used were DMF, ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, water, hexane, and acetone. The photoluminescence spectra of all compounds (1 mg), suspended in the different solvents (1 mL), were measured. As shown in , the spectrum showed an emission around 350 nm upon excitation at 300 nm for all complexes in the above solvents except in water for compounds 1-b, which showed an emission around 380 nm. The emission intensities were dependent on the solvent molecules, displaying the strongest emission in water for complex 1-b. All compounds show quenching in acetone solvent.

elements.content: To examine the sensing abilities of 1–2 toward different NACs, fluorescence titration experiments were performed using DMF suspensions of 1–2 by gradually increasing the concentration of various nitro explosives in DMF solutions (100 ppm), including 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), and para-nitrophenol (PNP). 1 mg of each complexes was dispersed in 1 mL of DMF, and all the NACs analytes displayed varying degrees of the fluorescence quenching effect for the suspensions of 1–2 as shown in –.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of NACs

To examine the sensing abilities of 1-2 toward different NACs, fluorescence titration experiments were performed using DMF suspensions of 1-2 by gradually increasing the concentration of various nitro explosives in DMF solutions (100 ppm), including 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), and para-nitrophenol (PNP). 1 mg of each complexes was dispersed in 1 mL of DMF, and all the NACs analytes displayed varying degrees of the fluorescence quenching effect for the suspensions of 1-2 as shown in -.

elements.content: Concentration-dependent luminescence intensities of compound 1-a by the addition of different volumes of 100 ppm of NACs (a) 2,4-DNT, (b) m-DNB, and (c) PNP in DMF (excited at 300 nm). (d) The quenching efficiency K sv for 1-a on three NACs.
elements.clean_text: 6  Concentration-dependent luminescence intensities of compound 1-a by the addition of different volumes of 100 ppm of NACs (a) 2,4-DNT, (b) m-DNB, and (c) PNP in DMF (excited at 300 nm). (d) The quenching efficiency K sv for 1-a on three NACs.

elements.content: The fluorescence quenching efficiency can be quantitatively analyzed using the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: (I 0/I) = 1 + K sv[Q], where K sv is the quenching constant (M – 1), [Q] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the compounds suspension without and with the addition of the analytes, respectively. Complexes 1–2 showed distinct quenching effects on both three NACs with low detection limits with the same quenching efficiency order of PNP > 2,4-DNB > m-DNB (d, d, and d). Then the quenching constants K sv of all complexes toward each kind of NACs are compared. The K sv of 1-a, 1-b, and 2 on 2,4-DNT are 1.29 × 104, 1.44 × 104, and 1.08 × 104 (R 2 = 0.998, 0.994, and 0.994) with the order of 1-b > 1-a > 2. Meanwhile, the same order of K sv for m-DNB is observed that 0.74 × 104 (R 2 = 0.987) for 1-b > 0.66 × 104 for 1-a (R 2 = 0.990) > 0.62 × 104 for 2 (R 2 = 0.981). The K sv of three compounds for 2,4-DNB and for m-DNB show no distinct differences. However, the K sv constants of 1-a, 1-b, and 2 for quenching of PNP are 1.20 × 104, 4.54 × 104, and 1.86 × 104 (R 2 = 0.998, 0.991 and 0.992). Particularly, up to 90% emission of PNP was quenched for complex 1-b with a high K sv of 4.54 × 104 which is more than twice larger than that 1-a and 2 on PNP.

elements.content: The high stability of all compounds in various solvents prompted us to investigate its ability to sense metal cations as they are the important components in water as well as have key influences on human health and other biological tissues. To investigate the capacity of all compounds for detecting diverse metal ions, the EtOH/H2O (1:1) solutions of different metal ions (1000 ppm), including Li+, Na+, K+, Ca2+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Cd2+, was added separately to the suspensions of 1–2 (1 mg each compound in 1 mL of EtOH/​H2O), respectively, and tested under the same conditions. It is worth noting that the Fe3+ ion exhibited a remarkable quenching effect on the luminescence of all three complexes (). The different effects of Fe3+ from the other disturbing cations on the emission (Figure S9) suggested that complexes 1–2 could be considered as a promising luminescent probe to distinguish Fe3+ ions from numerous other metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Fe3+ Metal Cation

The high stability of all compounds in various solvents prompted us to investigate its ability to sense metal cations as they are the important components in water as well as have key influences on human health and other biological tissues. To investigate the capacity of all compounds for detecting diverse metal ions, the EtOH/H2O (1:1) solutions of different metal ions (1000 ppm), including Li+, Na+, K+, Ca2+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Cd2+, was added separately to the suspensions of 1-2 (1 mg each compound in 1 mL of EtOH/H2O), respectively, and tested under the same conditions. It is worth noting that the Fe3+ ion exhibited a remarkable quenching effect on the luminescence of all three complexes (). The different effects of Fe3+ from the other disturbing cations on the emission (Figure S9) suggested that complexes 1-2 could be considered as a promising luminescent probe to distinguish Fe3+ ions from numerous other metal ions.

elements.content: Moreover, to determine the sensitivity, the EtOH/H2O solution containing 200 ppm of Fe3+ ion was gradually titrated into the suspension of all compounds. The sequential quenching of the luminescence intensities at 360 nm was recorded with a gradual addition of different concentrations of Fe3+ water solution as shown in . The S–V equation analysis of quenching effects on Fe3+ showed the quenching constant K sv of complexes 1-a, 1-b, and 2 are 4.12 × 103, 6.57 × 103, and 3.76 × 103 with R 2 = 0.987, 0.973, and 0.992, respectively (d). However, it is found that the quenching efficiency I 0/I at low Fe3+ concentration (before 25 ppm) is 1-b > 2 > 1-a. Then the slope of 1-a raises up, which means 1-a will be a better choice to detect Fe3+ than 2, when the concentration of Fe3+ is over 40 ppm.

elements.content: The selective quenching effect on Fe3+ in the majority of porous MOFs is derived from the interaction between their functional sites and Fe3+ ions through the cationic exchange or a strong interaction between the frameworks and the introduced Fe3+, such as diffusion into the MOFs channels or attachment to the MOFs surface. The larger Cd2+ centers and the suitable porous size are the main factors for the best K sv value (6.57 × 103) of 1-b. However, the best K sv for Fe3+ detection, comparing with the sensing property of three compounds on NACs, is just at the similar K sv values of three compounds for m-DNB (0.74 × 104, 0.66 × 104, 0.62 × 104) which are much lower than other NACs.

elements.content: The luminescent emitting of MOFs could be changed and optimized by the encapsulation of Ln3+ cations. On the basis of the excellent luminescent performance of 1–2, the further research on Ln-loaded property of 1–2 was attractive. Each complex 1–2 (1 mg) was dispersed into 2 mL of EtOH/​H2O (1:1), and the luminescence intensities of complexes upon the incremental addition of 200 ppm Y3+ and Ln3+ cations (Ce3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+) were recorded. The luminescent emitting was shifted differently and remarkably enhanced, generating different light colors.
elements.clean_text:
Encapsulation of Y3+ and Ln3+ Cations

The luminescent emitting of MOFs could be changed and optimized by the encapsulation of Ln3+ cations. On the basis of the excellent luminescent performance of 1-2, the further research on Ln-loaded property of 1-2 was attractive. Each complex 1-2 (1 mg) was dispersed into 2 mL of EtOH/H2O (1:1), and the luminescence intensities of complexes upon the incremental addition of 200 ppm Y3+ and Ln3+ cations (Ce3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+) were recorded. The luminescent emitting was shifted differently and remarkably enhanced, generating different light colors.

elements.content: Five IIIB cations Y3+, Ce3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+ show remarkable luminescence peaks in the EtOH/​H2O suspension of two Zn-complexes 1-a and 2 as shown in a–f and Figure S10; however, only Tb3+ shows new luminescence peaks in Cd-complex 1-b as shown in g. The titration luminescent curves of the Y3+ cation show a quenching and red shift from 352 to 388 nm for 1-a and from 353 to 378 nm for 2, and two new increasing peaks at 492 and 548 nm (a,b). In c–f, the titration luminescent curves of Gd3+ and Tb3+ cations also show two new increasing peaks at 492 and 548 nm, but there is only quenching at 350 nm (1-a) and 353 nm (2) compared with the Y3+ cation. Particularly, as shown, the Cd-complex 2 shows specific luminescence enhancement on the Tb3+ cation (g) compared with other Ln3+ cations (h and Figure S10). The linearity of the luminescence enhancement was implemented by the (I/I 0) = K[Q] to estimate the enhancement efficiencies. As the Table S6 lists, the compounds 1–2 showed an order of 1-a_Tb 3+ > 2_Tb 3+ > 1-a_Gd 3+ > 1-a_Y 3+ > 2_Y 3+ > 2_Gd 3+ > 1-b_Tb 3+ > 1-a_Ce 3+ > 2_Ce 3+ > 1-a_Dy 3+ > 2_Dy 3+ on a series of IIIB cations with high K values. It is worth to note that two Zn-MOF 1-a and 2 were good capsules to load IIIB ions to be fluorescent emitting materials (Tb3+, Gd3+, Y3+), especially for Tb3+ with high K values 3.29 × 106 and 2.71 × 106. Although the intensity is weaker than other cations in two Zn-MOFs, the Cd-MOF 1-b specifically responds to Tb3+ (K = 6.27 × 104), which could be used for selective detection on Tb3+ cation.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized three hot-water-stable luminescent Zn and Cd MOFs with similar chemical components (M2:L1:​Sol3) and topology, however, different porous structure and properties by solvents control. The further characterization and research found that the three MOFs show excellent sensing on a series of NACs (PNP > 2,4-DNB > m-DNB) with low detection limits, especially a high K sv of 4.54 × 104 for 1-b on PNP. In addition, the three MOFs could highly sensitively detect the Fe3+ cation with the quenching efficiency order 1-b > 2 > 1-a. Moreover, the luminescent emissions were differently shifted and remarkably enhanced, generating different light colors when Y3+ and Ln3+ cations (Ce3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+) were encapsulated in MOFs 1–2. Two Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 were good capsules to load IIIB ions to be fluorescent emitting materials (Tb3+, Gd3+, Y3+), with the enhancement order is 1-a_Tb3+ > 2_Tb3+ > 1-a_Gd3+ > 1-a_Y3+ > 2_Y3+ > 2_Gd3+ . However, Cd-MOF 1-b only specifically responds to the Tb3+ cation. The excellent luminescent response on different transition, IIIB metal ions, and NACs molecules reveals that this kind of solid host–guest luminescent MOFs has remarkable applications for environmental monitoring and social security.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we synthesized three hot-water-stable luminescent Zn and Cd MOFs with similar chemical components (M2:L1:Sol3) and topology, however, different porous structure and properties by solvents control. The further characterization and research found that the three MOFs show excellent sensing on a series of NACs (PNP > 2,4-DNB > m-DNB) with low detection limits, especially a high K sv of 4.54 × 104 for 1-b on PNP. In addition, the three MOFs could highly sensitively detect the Fe3+ cation with the quenching efficiency order 1-b > 2 > 1-a. Moreover, the luminescent emissions were differently shifted and remarkably enhanced, generating different light colors when Y3+ and Ln3+ cations (Ce3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+) were encapsulated in MOFs 1-2. Two Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 were good capsules to load IIIB ions to be fluorescent emitting materials (Tb3+, Gd3+, Y3+), with the enhancement order is 1-a_Tb3+  > 2_Tb3+  > 1-a_Gd3+  > 1-a_Y3+  > 2_Y3+  > 2_Gd3+ . However, Cd-MOF 1-b only specifically responds to the Tb3+ cation. The excellent luminescent response on different transition, IIIB metal ions, and NACs molecules reveals that this kind of solid host-guest luminescent MOFs has remarkable applications for environmental monitoring and social security.

A solid mixture of biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetra­carboxylic acid (H4bptc, 25.08 mg, 0.076 mmol), and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (101.74 mg, 0.342 mmol), dissolved in a mixture of 4.0 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) and 4.0 mL of N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) in a sealed 20 mL screw-top glass bottle, was heated at 85 °C for 24 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature for 10 h, and the resulting crystals were filtered from the reaction mixture and washed with DMF.

cln_elements.content:
Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out to confirm the phase purity of complexes 1–2. The diffraction peaks of the simulated and experimental patterns correspond well, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples of compounds 1–2 as shown in a–c. Indeed, solvent loss does not significantly affect the crystal structures, with the powder diffraction patterns remaining largely unchanged after being heated at 85 °C for 8 h. The compounds are also very stable in water. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to examine the thermal stability of the porous framework of compounds 1–2. As shown in d, an initial weight loss due to the loss of uncoordinated solvent molecules is observed in the thermogravimetric curve. A second weight loss (33.14%) occurs in the temperature range of 130–293 °C and is attributed to the loss of the four coordinated molecules. The frameworks of Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 show better thermal stability (decompose at about 400 °C) compared with Cd-MOF 1-b (decomposes at about 350 °C).

Luminescence Properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1–2 were measured at room temperature. The free ligand H4bptc displays photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 405 nm (λex = 350 nm), which was assigned to intraligand π–π* transition. As shown in , compounds 1–2 show photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 350 nm, respectively (λex = 300 nm), which have the blue shift of 55 nm, compared with free ligand H4bptc. With Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) as a typical d10 configuration, the observed photoluminescence emissions should be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), or intraligand (π* → n/π* or π* → π) emission. The luminescent emission of MOFs is influenced by both central metal coordination and the property of coordinated ligands, which need to be considered when attempting to assemble new functional luminescent MOFs.
cln_elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Analysis

Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out to confirm the phase purity of complexes 1-2. The diffraction peaks of the simulated and experimental patterns correspond well, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples of compounds 1-2 as shown in a-c. Indeed, solvent loss does not significantly affect the crystal structures, with the powder diffraction patterns remaining largely unchanged after being heated at 85 °C for 8 h. The compounds are also very stable in water. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to examine the thermal stability of the porous framework of compounds 1-2. As shown in d, an initial weight loss due to the loss of uncoordinated solvent molecules is observed in the thermogravimetric curve. A second weight loss (33.14%) occurs in the temperature range of 130-293 °C and is attributed to the loss of the four coordinated molecules. The frameworks of Zn-MOFs 1-a and 2 show better thermal stability (decompose at about 400 °C) compared with Cd-MOF 1-b (decomposes at about 350 °C).

Luminescence Properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-2 were measured at room temperature. The free ligand H4bptc displays photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 405 nm (λex = 350 nm), which was assigned to intraligand π-π* transition. As shown in , compounds 1-2 show photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 350 nm, respectively (λex = 300 nm), which have the blue shift of 55 nm, compared with free ligand H4bptc. With Zn(II) and Cd(II) as a typical d10 configuration, the observed photoluminescence emissions should be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), or intraligand (π* → n/π* or π* → π) emission. The luminescent emission of MOFs is influenced by both central metal coordination and the property of coordinated ligands, which need to be considered when attempting to assemble new functional luminescent MOFs.
